text.author: Neil Levy
text.title: Taking responsibility for health in an epistemically polluted environment
text.summary1: (human1) This paper explains epistemic pollution, the result of an environment in which scholarly information may be false or deceptive, using examples of the potential harm caused by this phenomenon.
text.summary2: (claude-3-5-sonnet-20241022) The article discusses how epistemic pollution occurs when individuals or institutions deliberately mimic markers of expertise to deceive others, making it increasingly difficult for people to distinguish genuine experts from charlatans and undermining trust in legitimate sources.
text.summary3: (gpt4o; postedited) The article addresses epistemic pollution, where deceptive organizations and questionable practices within legitimate ones manipulate markers of expertise, undermining public trust in expert authority and making it challenging for the public and professionals to distinguish genuine expertise from fraudulent or biased claims.
text.summary4: (Llama-3.2-3B-Instruct) The proliferation of fake or deceptive institutions claiming to be experts in various fields, such as healthcare and academia, has led to widespread epistemic pollution, eroding trust in expert authority and making it difficult for ordinary people to distinguish reliable from unreliable sources.
text.summary5: (Qwen2.5-7B-Instruct) The proliferation of counterfeit institutions and unethical practices within legitimate institutions creates “epistemic pollution” that undermines public trust in expert authority and makes it increasingly difficult for both experts and non-experts to discern credible sources.
